questions.text: Which family does yellow fever virus belong to?
questions.solution:
Yellow fever virus belongs to the family flaviviridae, which contains the genus Flavivirus.

The important species under genus Flavivirus include: 

  • Yellow fever virus
  • Dengue virus
  • Japanese encephalitis virus
  • Kyasanur forest disease virus
  • West Nile encephalitis
  • Zikavirus

Note: Arbovirus is a term used to refer to any viruses that are transmitted by arthropod vectors. There is no family or order by the name arbovirus. The word arbovirus stands for ARthropod-BOrne virus. 

Related Pearl: Taxonomy of Arboviruses

FAMILY

GENUS

IMPORTANT SPECIES

Togaviridae

Alphavirus

Chikungunya, Eastern equine encephalitis virus, Western equine encephalitis virus, Venezuelan equine encephalitis virus 

Flaviviridae

Flavivirus

Japanese encephalitis, West Nile virus, Dengue virus, Kayasanur forest disease virus, Murray valley encephalitis virus, Yellow fever virus, Zika virus

Bunyavirus

California encephalitis

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy from Uttar Pradesh was rushed to the emergency department with a headache, fever, and blurred vision followed shortly by unresponsiveness to verbal commands. He is suspected to have viral encephalitis. Which of the following transmits this endemic disease?
questions.solution:
Endemic viral encephalitis is suggestive of Japanese encephalitis. It is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnuii.

It is the leading cause of childhood neurological viral infection in India. In endemic areas such as North India, it typically affects children <15 years of age as by early adulthood, the majority of the population has protective immunity following natural exposure to the virus.

Ardeid birds like herons and egrets are reservoir hosts, while the amplifier hosts are pigs. It is transmitted by Culex mosquitoes, and human infection is a tangential dead end.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis?

choices.text: Vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control

questions.solution:
Humans are the dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis virus.

Option A: The disease is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

Option B: Herons act as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifier hosts.

Option D: The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings and vaccinating pigs.

The image below shows the life cycle of the Japanese B encephalitis virus.

questions.text: A mother brings her 9-month-old child for vaccination against Japanese encephalitis. Which of the following statements is false regarding this vaccine?

choices.text: Two doses are recommended at age 9 months and 18 months
Inactivated vero cell culture is given 4 weeks apart
Live vaccine SA 14-14-2 is administered intramuscularly
The live attenuated vaccine can be given to adolescents

questions.solution:
Live SA 14-14-2 strain of Japanese encephalitis (JE) vaccine is administered subcutaneously.

Types of JE Vaccines:

  SA 14-14-2 cell culture derived vaccine  Inactivated vero cell culture derived Kolar (Jenvac 82156XY)
Live attenuated Inactivated
Route of administration Subcutaneous Intramuscular Intramuscular
 Dosage 2 doses 2 doses 2 doses
 Duration between doses At ages 9months and 16-18 months 4 weeks apart 4 weeks apart
 Ages 9 months, 16-18 months, adolescents and non-immune adults up to 15 years  up to 18 years

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, arthralgia, and pain behind the eyes for 3 days. On examination, she has the following rash. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and leucopenia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the symptoms and the rash suggests dengue fever.

It presents with sudden-onset fever, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, and a rash. The rash in dengue appears as white islands on a red sea due to erythema with petechiae. The alternative name for dengue, breakbone fever, comes from the associated muscle and joint pains.

Suspected cases of dengue are confirmed by the presence of NS1 antigen or IgM antibodies.

The treatment of dengue is supportive with hydration taking top priority.

questions.text: A 35-year-old wildlife photographer presents with sudden onset of fever, headache, and myalgia. On examination, you notice gingival bleeds and conjunctival hemorrhages. He recently visited a forest in Karnataka that has a large population of monkeys.  Which of these is the vector for the suspected disease?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with exposure to monkeys, fever, myalgia, headache, conjunctival hemorrhage and gingival bleeds is suggestive of Kyasanur forest disease (KFD), which is transmitted by ticks (Haemophysalis spinigera). It is endemic to the forests of Karnataka and Kerala.

The clinical features include:

  • Fever
  • Headache
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Myalgia 
  • Meningoencephalitis
  • Hemorrhagic symptoms- hemorrhages in skin, mucosa and gastrointestinal bleeds.

The case fatality rate is about 5 percent.

Monkeys are amplifier hosts, rodents are reservoirs and humans are incidental hosts.

A killed KFD virus vaccine was used in a small field trial and appeared to provide some degree of protection.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with delirium, fever, jaundice, and a hemorrhagic diathesis. The patient is agitated and has had no urine output in the last 6 hours. On investigation, there is azotemia and elevated liver enzymes. A viral disease with the vector shown below is suspected. Which of the following inclusion bodies may be seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows the Aedes aegypti mosquito and the clinical scenario with hepatic and renal dysfunction with delirium points towards a diagnosis of yellow fever. Torres bodies are amorphous eosinophilic nuclear inclusions associated with yellow fever, a disease caused by the Flavivirus.

Inclusion bodies are structures with distinct sizes and shapes that are seen in virus-infected cells under light microscopy.

Note: Dengue hemorrhagic fever can be a differential diagnosis, but there are no inclusion bodies seen in dengue. 

Related Pearl: Inclusion bodies seen in various conditions/diseases

questions.text: What is the duration of validity of 17D vaccination?
questions.solution:
17D vaccine (yellow fever vaccine) is valid for a lifetime, beginning 10 days after vaccination. According to the amendment in 2016 to International Health Regulations 2005, the validity of the related international certificate of vaccination against yellow fever has been changed from ten (10) years to the lifespan of the person (traveler) vaccinated.

It is a live-attenuated vaccine derived from the 'Asibi strain', administered subcutaneously. Immunity after a single dose is long-lasting and provides lifetime protection. It is thermolabile. 

Vaccination is compulsory for travel to and from endemic areas.

In India, 17D is manufactured at the Central Research Institute, Kasauli.

 

Related Pearl: Diseases of International Significance

questions.text: A pest control technician with a history of fever, vomiting, hematuria, and decreased urine output was diagnosed with hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome. Which of the following statements is false about the causative virus?

choices.text: Hantaviruses are the natural pathogens of rodents
Transmission primarily occurs by Culex mosquitoes
Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome presents with pulmonary edema

questions.solution:
Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) is caused by Hantaviruses. They are rodent-borne viruses that are transmitted by inhalation of the virus contained in dried excreta of rodents. They are the natural pathogens of rodents like mice, rats, and voles. 

HFRS presents with acute kidney injury, hemorrhages, fever, and circulatory collapse. Hantaviruses can also cause Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome.

Note: In Aug 2016, The International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV), has renamed and moved the genus Hantavirus to Orthohantavirus.

questions.text: An epidemic of paralytic poliomyelitis occurs in a non-immune population. Which among the following strains of poliovirus is the most common cause of this?
questions.solution:
Type 1 poliovirus is the most common cause of epidemics in populations.

Poliovirus strains have been classified into 3 types: 

  • Type 1- most common and causes most of the epidemics. 
  • Type 2- endemic infections. 
  • Type 3- epidemics but rarer than type 1. 

Immunity is type-specific. 

Note :- Type 2 is declared eradicated in September, 2015 and Type 3 is declared eradicated in October, 2019

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrics OPD with a history of lower-limb paralysis and the following deformity. Which of the following will be the most common form of presentation of this illness?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with a history of lower limb paralysis and deformity is suggestive of poliomyelitis. The given image shows deformity of the right lower limb, namely hyperextension at the knee joint and muscle wasting. 

Inapparent infection is the most common (90-95%) presentation of polio. Only seroconversion occurs without any clinical manifestations. 

Option B: Abortive poliomyelitis is associated with primary viremia and presents as fever, headache, sore throat, and malaise lasting for 1-5 days.

Option C: Paralytic poliomyelitis occurs following minor illness, characterized by biphasic fever with headache, stiff neck, and flaccid paralysis. 

Option D: In non-paralytic poliomyelitis, the disease does not progress beyond the stage of aseptic meningitis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old unimmunized patient presents to you with complaints of weakness of lower limbs, inability to pass urine, and fever, for 3 days. His stool samples were sent to the district lab to confirm the diagnosis. Which region of the spinal cord will primarily be affected in these cases?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario of fever, lower limb paralysis, urinary retention, and stool samples being sent for diagnosis, is suggestive of paralytic polio. The anterior horn cells of the spinal cord are primarily affected, causing acute flaccid paralysis. Posterior horns and intermediate columns/lateral horns may also be involved to some extent. 

In the central nervous system, the virus multiplies selectively in the neurons and destroys them. The earliest change is the degeneration of Nissl bodies (chromatolysis). Nuclear changes follow. 

Note: Fecal samples of all cases of acute flaccid paralysis are obtained (2 samples) and transported to the laboratory within 72 hours of collection at 4–8°C or frozen at -20°C. This is known as the reverse cold chain and is done as a part of gold standard polio surveillance/acute flaccid paralysis surveillance (AFP surveillance).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding vaccination against polio?

choices.text: Sabin type has the live attenuated virus
OPV should not be administered to immunocompromised persons
Salk vaccine is associated with mutations that lead to reversal of virulence
Both OPV and IPV induce humoral IgG

questions.solution:
Salk type is the killed vaccine, hence there is no risk of mutation that can lead to a reversal of virulence. 

There are two types of vaccines for polio - IPV (inactivated poliovirus vaccine) and OPV (oral poliovirus vaccine). 

Related Pearl: Inactivated and Live Attenuated Polio Vaccines

Characteristic

Inactivated (IPV/Salk)

Attenuated (OPV/Sabin)
Prevents disease Yes Yes
Induces humoral IgG Yes Yes
Induces intestinal sIgA No Yes
Prevents intestinal colonization No Yes
Secondary (herd) protection by spread to others No Yes
Reverts to virulence No Yes, very rarely
May cause disease in immunocompromised No Yes

Salk has K, so it is killed.

questions.text: Which of the following strains of poliovirus have been eradicated worldwide?
questions.solution:
Type 2 and 3 have been eradicated worldwide.

Type 2: In September 2015, WHO declared the eradication of the wild type 2 poliovirus strain. In India, the last type 2 infection was detected in 1999.

Type 3: It has not been detected anywhere in the world since November 2012. On World Polio Day in October 2019, the type 3 virus was declared to be eradicated worldwide.

The only circulating strain is type 1.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presented with acute chest pain which was stabbing type in nature. The pain is spasmodic and associated with fever spikes. There's an outbreak of coxsackievirus B in her community. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with stabbing type chest pain which is spasmodic in nature, associated with fever spikes, and history of an outbreak of coxsackievirus B is suggestive of Bornholm disease or epidemic pleurodynia. 

Symptoms include paroxysms of acute pleuritic chest pain associated with fever spikes. Involved muscles are tender. Chest X-ray is usually normal. Most cases occur during epidemics of coxsackievirus B. The disease is named after the Danish island of Bornholm where early cases occurred.  

The treatment is non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents or hot fomentation of the involved muscles. 

Other diseases associated with coxsackievirus B:

  • Neonatal myocarditis and pericarditis
  • Juvenile diabetes mellitus
  • Orchitis
  • Severe disseminated congenital infection- hepatitis, meningoencephalitis, adrenocortical involvement

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with headache, fever, and vomiting. On examination, you observe the following. He is diagnosed with herpangina. Which group of viruses causes the same?
questions.solution:
The given image shows palatal ulcers in herpangina. It is caused by the coxsackievirus A, a large subgroup of the enteroviruses.

Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis is characterized by grayish- white papulovesicular lesions on an erythematous base that ulcerate. These are present on:

  • Soft palate
  • Anterior pillars of tonsils
  • Uvula
  • Posterior oropharynx

It is a common clinical manifestation of coxsackievirus A infection in children, but it can also be caused by coxsackievirus B, echoviruses, or enterovirus 71.

Treatment is usually only supportive, as the disease is self-limiting and usually runs its course in less than a week.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes the following disease?
questions.solution:
The image shows vesicles on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa, consistent with hand-foot-and-mouth disease. It is caused by coxsackievirus.

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young children, characterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs. Vesicles heal without crusting, which clinically differentiates them from the vesicles of herpesviruses and poxviruses. It is usually a benign illness resolving in 1-2 weeks.

Coxsackie A16, A9, and B 1-3 are common causative agents.

Other diseases caused by Coxsackie A virus:

  • Aseptic meningitis associated with a maculopapular rash.
  • Herpangina
  • Minor respiratory infections

questions.text: A 60-year-old presented with eye pain, watering of eyes, and increased sensitivity to light. On examination, you see the following. Which of the following viruses can cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis (AHC) caused mainly by Enterovirus 70 and Coxsackievirus A24 variant (CA24v).

It is characterized by sudden swelling, congestion, and watering of the eyes. Subconjunctival hemorrhages are a characteristic feature and corneal involvement may occur transiently. 

There is no treatment currently available. The disease is self limiting, and resolves within a five to seven-day period.

Note: Acute follicular conjunctivitis is caused by Adenovirus serotypes 3, 4, 7 and 11.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presented with fever, joint pains, and headache. Chik sign (image given below) is present on the patient's nose. Which of the following vectors transmits the etiological agent?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with fever, joint pain, headache, and Chik sign is suggestive of chikungunya which is transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes.

Chikungunya presents with sudden onset of fever, crippling joint pain, lymphadenopathy, and conjunctivitis. The fever is typically biphasic with a period of remission after 1–6 days. Nose pigmentation is striking in cases of Chikungunya fever and is termed as Chik sign

No animal reservoir has been identified.

Note: Although Chikungunya is transmitted by both Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, A.Aegypti is considered primary vector of transmission for Chikungunya.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters

  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days
